contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=January 2010}}{{More footnotes|date=January 2010}} [[Image:Infoseeklogo.png|thumb|A known logo]] '''Infoseek''' was a popular [[search engine]] founded in 1994 by [[Steve Kirsch]]. Infoseek was originally operated by the '''Infoseek Corporation''', headquartered in [[Sunnyvale, California]].<ref>"[http://web.archive.org/web/19970702014416/info.infoseek.com/doc/contact.html Contacting Infoseek]." Infoseek. July 2, 1997. Retrieved on January 20, 2010.</ref> Infoseek was bought by [[The Walt Disney Company]] in 1998, and the technology was merged with that of the Disney-acquired [[Starwave]] to form the [[Go.com]] network. Since then it has been replaced with [[Yahoo!]] search and is no longer in use. == Features == Infoseek featured a very complex system of [[search modifiers]], including [[Boolean logic|boolean]] modifiers such as the most basic "OR" and "NOT", parentheses, and quotes, up to being able to say that one wanted one word or phrase to appear within ''x'' number of words from another word or phrase. Before being bought by Disney, Infoseek also offered a free [[web hosting]] package. It was free of [[Internet advertising|advertising]], and had no limit on the amount of file storage space that could be used. Advertising was added after the Disney purchase. == History == By September 1997, Infoseek boasted 7.3 million visitors per month.<ref name="source">[http://web.archive.org/web/20090501140446/http://www.clubi.ie/webserch/engines/infoseek/history.htm Infoseek - a history (from WebSerch)]</ref> It bought out the [[WebChat Broadcasting System]] in April 1998. Infoseek was bought by [[The Walt Disney Company]] in 1998, and the technology was merged with that of the Disney-acquired [[Starwave]] to form the [[Go.com]] network. Infoseek was the first search engine to sell advertising on a CPM (Cost Per Thousand Impressions) basis. In 1996, then east coast Sales Manager, Robert Formentin sold the first Cost Per Click programs as well as the precursor to pop-ups called daughter windows to Grey Advertising for a [[Procter & Gamble]] [[Pampers]] campaign. In 1997 Infoseek was the first internet company to develop and launch [[behavioral targeting]] via its UltraMatch targeting algorithms. In 1999, Infoseek engineer [[Li Yanhong]] moved to [[Beijing]], [[China]] and co-founded the search engine [[Baidu]]. In February 2001, Disney made the decision to cancel the service and lay off the entire staff. Eventually,{{When|date=January 2010}} the hosting service was shut down. In 2001 Bernt Wahl, Andy Bensky and 15 software engineers—Infoseek employees—led a management buyout attempt from Disney but were ultimately rebuffed. Infoseek's [[Ultraseek]] Server software technology, an enterprise search engine product, was sold in 2000 to [[Inktomi (company)|Inktomi]]. Under Inktomi, Ultraseek Server was renamed "Inktomi Enterprise Search". In December 2002 (prior to [[Yahoo]]'s acquisition of Inktomi), the Ultraseek product suite was sold to a competitor [[Verity Inc]], who re-established the Ultraseek brand name and continued development of the product. In December 2005, Verity was acquired by UK company [[Autonomy Corporation|Autonomy PLC]]. Under Autonomy, Ultraseek continues to be actively developed and marketed as Autonomy's entry-level keyword-based site search offering. == Domain name == Today, the "infoseek.com" [[domain name]] forwards to the "go.com" website. The brand name of Infoseek is now completely unused in North America; however it is still operating as [http://www.infoseek.co.jp Infoseek Japan]. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area|Companies}} * [http://web.archive.org/*/http://www.infoseek.com Infoseek] (Archive) * [http://www.infoseek.co.jp/ Infoseek Japan] [[Category:Internet search engines]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 1994]] [[Category:2001 disestablishments]] [[Category:Companies based in Sunnyvale, California]] [[Category:Disney acquisitions]]
